<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10)-a [<ce:bold>lig</ce:bold> (LiGe)] topology. Complex [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(DMF)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">

elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

The 3:2 CuCl2/1,4-dihydro-2,3-quinoxalinedione reaction system in DMF in the presence of OH-s gives a structurally and magnetically interesting 3D coordination polymer possessing the 2,3-dioxyquinoxalinate(-2) ligand (L2-) and exhibiting the extremely rare (82 ⋅10)-a [lig (LiGe)] topology. Complex [Cu3L2Cl2(DMF)4] n  is the first coordination polymer of any metal with L2- and contains the dianionic ligand in the novel 3.1111 mode.

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">The reaction of 1,4-dihydro-2,3-quinoxalinedione (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L′) with CuCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> in the presence of LiOH in DMF has led to the 3D coordination polymer [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(DMF)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) with an (8<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10)-a, <ce:bold>lig</ce:bold> (LiGe), topology, where L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> is 2,3-dioxyquinoxalinate(−2). This compound is the first coordination polymer of any transition metal featuring L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> and contains the ligand in a novel 3.1111 (Harris notation) coordination mode. IR data are discussed in terms of the chemical composition of the polymer and the coordination mode of L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>. Variable-temperature (2–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K) magnetic susceptibility and variable-field (0–5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>T) magnetization studies reveal that L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> propagates weak antiferromagnetic exchange interactions through its “quinoxaline” moiety.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

The reaction of 1,4-dihydro-2,3-quinoxalinedione (H2L') with CuCl2 in the presence of LiOH in DMF has led to the 3D coordination polymer [Cu3L2Cl2(DMF)4] n  (1) with an (82 ⋅10)-a, lig (LiGe), topology, where L2- is 2,3-dioxyquinoxalinate(-2). This compound is the first coordination polymer of any transition metal featuring L2- and contains the ligand in a novel 3.1111 (Harris notation) coordination mode. IR data are discussed in terms of the chemical composition of the polymer and the coordination mode of L2-. Variable-temperature (2-300K) magnetic susceptibility and variable-field (0-5T) magnetization studies reveal that L2- propagates weak antiferromagnetic exchange interactions through its "quinoxaline" moiety.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The rapidly growing field of coordination polymers  has given rise to a wide variety of fascinating one-(1D), two-(2D) and three-dimensional (3D) structures. The current great interest in the synthesis of new coordination polymers is also due to their potential applications as functional molecular materials in many fields and areas, such as catalysis, electrical conductivity, luminescence, non-linear optics, magnetism, medicine, gas storage, anion separation and ion exchange . Their properties originate either from the metal centres and/or the organic components.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The rapidly growing field of coordination polymers  has given rise to a wide variety of fascinating one-(1D), two-(2D) and three-dimensional (3D) structures. The current great interest in the synthesis of new coordination polymers is also due to their potential applications as functional molecular materials in many fields and areas, such as catalysis, electrical conductivity, luminescence, non-linear optics, magnetism, medicine, gas storage, anion separation and ion exchange . Their properties originate either from the metal centres and/or the organic components.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">A frequently used family of organic linkers for the assembly of coordination polymers consists of a dicarboxylates, <ce:sup loc="pre">−</ce:sup>OOC–X–COO<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, with a highly varied array of X units . The question naturally arose as to whether diamidate, <ce:sup loc="pre">−</ce:sup>RNOC–X–CONR<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, or diamide, RHNCO–X–CONHR, ligands and amides of dicarboxylates, RHNCO–X–COO<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> (or their dianionic derivatives <ce:sup loc="pre">−</ce:sup>RNCO–X–COO<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) would be also efficient-like dicarboxylates-in bridging metal ions and effecting electronic coupling between them (R<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>various non-coordinating and coordinating groups). The answer has been provided by several groups , including our research group  for the family of ligands that contain both an amide and a carboxylate functionality.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: A frequently used family of organic linkers for the assembly of coordination polymers consists of a dicarboxylates, -OOC-X-COO-, with a highly varied array of X units . The question naturally arose as to whether diamidate, -RNOC-X-CONR-, or diamide, RHNCO-X-CONHR, ligands and amides of dicarboxylates, RHNCO-X-COO- (or their dianionic derivatives -RNCO-X-COO-) would be also efficient-like dicarboxylates-in bridging metal ions and effecting electronic coupling between them (R=various non-coordinating and coordinating groups). The answer has been provided by several groups , including our research group  for the family of ligands that contain both an amide and a carboxylate functionality.

</mml:math> complexes, we have recognized that there is a special class of cyclic diamidates that have no dicarboxylate analogues and that these could bridge 3 or 4 metal ions leading to coordination polymers. One such ligand, 1,4-dihydro-2,3-dioxyquinoxalinedione (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L′), and its <ce:italic>diolate</ce:italic> dianion, 2,3-dioxyquinoxalinate (L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>), are depicted in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>; for simplicity the two ligands are shown in the tautomeric forms established by crystallography. Our primary goal in this project is to see how much synthetic chemistry can be accomplished by employing the neutral and anionic forms of this and related ligands (e.g. 2,3-dioxypyrazinate(−2) and 4,6-dioxypyrimidinate(−2)) as linkers for the construction of coordination polymers. A secondary goal is to test the antitumour activity and DNA properties of the <ce:italic>monomeric</ce:italic> (if any) metal complexes with the quinoxaline-based ligands H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L′ and L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>, since such complexes have a tradition in exhibiting such properties . In the preliminary work reported here, we have sought the answers to two main questions: (i) Can copper(II) coordination polymers be made containing the ligands shown in  (or tautomers thereof)? (ii) How effective will these linkers be in mediating magnetic exchange interactions between Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ions?</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Inspired by the ideas of Chisholm et al. , Murillo and the late Cotton  on the linking of quadruply bonded     Mo   2   4 +     units to give   (   Mo   2   4 +     )   2     complexes, we have recognized that there is a special class of cyclic diamidates that have no dicarboxylate analogues and that these could bridge 3 or 4 metal ions leading to coordination polymers. One such ligand, 1,4-dihydro-2,3-dioxyquinoxalinedione (H2L'), and its diolate dianion, 2,3-dioxyquinoxalinate (L2-), are depicted in  ; for simplicity the two ligands are shown in the tautomeric forms established by crystallography. Our primary goal in this project is to see how much synthetic chemistry can be accomplished by employing the neutral and anionic forms of this and related ligands (e.g. 2,3-dioxypyrazinate(-2) and 4,6-dioxypyrimidinate(-2)) as linkers for the construction of coordination polymers. A secondary goal is to test the antitumour activity and DNA properties of the monomeric (if any) metal complexes with the quinoxaline-based ligands H2L' and L2-, since such complexes have a tradition in exhibiting such properties . In the preliminary work reported here, we have sought the answers to two main questions: (i) Can copper(II) coordination polymers be made containing the ligands shown in  (or tautomers thereof)? (ii) How effective will these linkers be in mediating magnetic exchange interactions between CuII ions?

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Heating a solution of [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CMe)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>], CuCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L′ (3:1:3) in DMF at 130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in a sealed tube for 6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, followed by slow cooling down to ambient temperature, gave dark green crystals of [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (DMF)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) directly from the reaction solution; the yield was ca. 50% . With the identity of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> established by crystallography , a convenient synthesis of the pure material was sought under alternative reaction conditions. Thus, the reaction of three equivalents of CuCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> with two equivalents of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L′, in the presence of four equivalents of LiOH<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, in DMF and layering of Et<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (1:1 v/v) onto the resulting olive green solution gave dark green crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; the yield is ∼70%.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Heating a solution of [Cu2(O2CMe)4 (H2O)2], CuCl2 and H2L' (3:1:3) in DMF at 130°C in a sealed tube for 6h, followed by slow cooling down to ambient temperature, gave dark green crystals of [Cu3L2Cl2 (DMF)4] n  (1) directly from the reaction solution; the yield was ca. 50% . With the identity of 1 established by crystallography , a convenient synthesis of the pure material was sought under alternative reaction conditions. Thus, the reaction of three equivalents of CuCl2 with two equivalents of H2L', in the presence of four equivalents of LiOH⋅H2O, in DMF and layering of Et2O (1:1 v/v) onto the resulting olive green solution gave dark green crystals of 1; the yield is ~70%.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a 3D coordination polymer built from centrosymmetric trinuclear [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(DMF)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] units containing 2,3-dioxyquinoxalinate(−2) (L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> in , vide infra) ligands that are responsible for the polymer creation. A perspective view of the trinuclear unit is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>. Within the crystallographic asymmetric unit there are two, structurally different Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> sites, Cu(1) and Cu(2). The central Cu(1) ion sits on an inversion centre exhibiting <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> coordination to two terminal chlorides and to two symmetry related L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> the one of nitrogen atoms ((N1)) in each ligand. Each of the two “terminal” Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ions (Cu(2), Cu(2′)) is bonded to two oxygen atoms of two terminal DMF molecules, both oxygen atoms from one L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand and to one nitrogen atom (N(2)) from an equivalent ligand in a different asymmetric unit.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compound 1 is a 3D coordination polymer built from centrosymmetric trinuclear [Cu3L2Cl2(DMF)4] units containing 2,3-dioxyquinoxalinate(-2) (L2- in , vide infra) ligands that are responsible for the polymer creation. A perspective view of the trinuclear unit is shown in  . Within the crystallographic asymmetric unit there are two, structurally different CuII sites, Cu(1) and Cu(2). The central Cu(1) ion sits on an inversion centre exhibiting trans coordination to two terminal chlorides and to two symmetry related L2- ligands via the one of nitrogen atoms ((N1)) in each ligand. Each of the two "terminal" CuII ions (Cu(2), Cu(2')) is bonded to two oxygen atoms of two terminal DMF molecules, both oxygen atoms from one L2- ligand and to one nitrogen atom (N(2)) from an equivalent ligand in a different asymmetric unit.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The coordination geometry around Cu(1) is square planar. The Cu(2) coordination geometry is well described as square pyramidal with the DMF oxygen O(3) occupying the apical position. As expected, the axial Cu(2)–O(3) bond is the longest (2.336(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The coordination geometry around Cu(1) is square planar. The Cu(2) coordination geometry is well described as square pyramidal with the DMF oxygen O(3) occupying the apical position. As expected, the axial Cu(2)-O(3) bond is the longest (2.336(2)Å).

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">In solution, 1,4-dihydro-2,3-quinoxalinedione (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L′, ) is in equilibrium with the tautomers with one and two hydroxyl groups . The question of which tautomer is predominant in the solid state was clearly answered with the help of single-crystal X-ray crystallography some thirty years ago ; this technique revealed that the molecule is a dione (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L′ in ). A comparison of the structural data for the dianionic ligand in complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with those of the free ligand H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L′  shows that the excess electron density of the deprotonated nitrogen atom is partially delocalized over the oxygen atoms of the amido groups; this permits the formulation of the resonance structures <ce:bold>I</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>II</ce:bold>
, see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>. The CN bond lengths between the carbon atoms of the phenyl ring and nitrogen atoms in the heterocyclic ring for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (1.384 and 1.390<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) are typical of those of a single C–N bond, as in the case of the free ligand (1.392 and 1.398<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) . Moreover, the C–N<ce:inf loc="post">“amide”</ce:inf> bond distances in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (C(1)–N(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.316<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, C(2)–N(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.318<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), which are less than the corresponding distances in the free ligand (1.337 and 1.345<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), indicate the existence of single bonds. Thus, the CN bond distances of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are consistent with the dominance of the resonance form <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> (see ) in the real structure of the coordinated dianionic ligand ; for this reason, the dianionic ligand is represented using the form <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> in  (vide infra).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In solution, 1,4-dihydro-2,3-quinoxalinedione (H2L', ) is in equilibrium with the tautomers with one and two hydroxyl groups . The question of which tautomer is predominant in the solid state was clearly answered with the help of single-crystal X-ray crystallography some thirty years ago ; this technique revealed that the molecule is a dione (H2L' in ). A comparison of the structural data for the dianionic ligand in complex 1 with those of the free ligand H2L'  shows that the excess electron density of the deprotonated nitrogen atom is partially delocalized over the oxygen atoms of the amido groups; this permits the formulation of the resonance structures I and II , see  . The CN bond lengths between the carbon atoms of the phenyl ring and nitrogen atoms in the heterocyclic ring for 1 (1.384 and 1.390Å) are typical of those of a single C-N bond, as in the case of the free ligand (1.392 and 1.398Å) . Moreover, the C-N"amide" bond distances in 1 (C(1)-N(1)=1.316Å, C(2)-N(2)=1.318Å), which are less than the corresponding distances in the free ligand (1.337 and 1.345Å), indicate the existence of single bonds. Thus, the CN bond distances of 1 are consistent with the dominance of the resonance form II (see ) in the real structure of the coordinated dianionic ligand ; for this reason, the dianionic ligand is represented using the form II in  (vide infra).

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The structural elements that are present in the repeat trinuclear unit of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> arrange into a half folded square ring consisting of four Cu(1) and four Cu(2) ions and eight L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>); each of these ligands is then coordinated through a square pyramidal copper (Cu(2)) <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> either nitrogen or both oxygens alternately to form a 3D coordination polymer. In this arrangement, the L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands serve as “T” shaped three-connected nodes while the Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> centres serve as linear bridges, creating a rather uncommon and extremely rare  three-connected (8<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10)-a network also known as <ce:bold>lig</ce:bold> (LiGe) , see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>
. Given the relative roles of the ligands which serve as nodes and the metal centres which serve as bridges within the (8<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10)-a network, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be also characterized as an inverted metal–organic framework (IMOF) .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The structural elements that are present in the repeat trinuclear unit of 1 arrange into a half folded square ring consisting of four Cu(1) and four Cu(2) ions and eight L2- ligands ( ); each of these ligands is then coordinated through a square pyramidal copper (Cu(2)) via either nitrogen or both oxygens alternately to form a 3D coordination polymer. In this arrangement, the L2- ligands serve as "T" shaped three-connected nodes while the CuII centres serve as linear bridges, creating a rather uncommon and extremely rare  three-connected (82 ⋅10)-a network also known as lig (LiGe) , see   . Given the relative roles of the ligands which serve as nodes and the metal centres which serve as bridges within the (82 ⋅10)-a network, 1 can be also characterized as an inverted metal-organic framework (IMOF) .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The ligand L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> adopts the 3.1111 (using Harris notation ) coordination mode in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig6"></ce:float-anchor>). This is a novel coordination mode for this ligand. Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> joins a handful of structurally characterized metal complexes containing H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L′ or L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> as ligands . The ligands H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L′ and L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> have been observed in four ligation modes in these complexes (including <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>). The observed coordination modes are shown in . The metric parameters of L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> in all the previous complexes support its formulation as shown in , i.e. the dominance of the resonance form <ce:bold>II</ce:bold> (see ). Thus compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is the first crystallographically characterized metal complex in which 2,3-dioxyquinoxalinate(−2) coordinates in the ene-1,2-diolate mode as a bridging ligand.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The ligand L2- adopts the 3.1111 (using Harris notation ) coordination mode in 1 ( ). This is a novel coordination mode for this ligand. Complex 1 joins a handful of structurally characterized metal complexes containing H2L' or L2- as ligands . The ligands H2L' and L2- have been observed in four ligation modes in these complexes (including 1). The observed coordination modes are shown in . The metric parameters of L2- in all the previous complexes support its formulation as shown in , i.e. the dominance of the resonance form II (see ). Thus compound 1 is the first crystallographically characterized metal complex in which 2,3-dioxyquinoxalinate(-2) coordinates in the ene-1,2-diolate mode as a bridging ligand.

elements.clean_text: Solid-state dc magnetic susceptibility data ( ) were collected on dried 1 under a constant field of 0.1T in the temperature range 2.0-300K. The product χ M T at room temperature is 1.17cm3 mol-1 K per trinuclear unit, close to the value of 1.24cm3 mol-1 K expected for three interacting CuII ions with a g value of 2.1. The value of the χ M T product decreases gradually upon cooling until ca. 60K, and below this temperature, it decreases quickly down to a value of 0.62cm3 Kmol-1 at 6K, before increasing sharply at lower temperatures; the χ M T value is 0.81cm3 Kmol-1 at 2.0K. Magnetization experiments performed at 2.0K in the field range 0-5T indicate a saturation value close to one electron per     Cu   3   II     unit exhibiting a Brillouin shape for S =1/2 and g =2.06(4).

elements.clean_text: For a 3D compound in which all the superexchange pathways were operative and antiferromagnetic in nature, an S =0 "ground state" would be expected in the absence of competitive interactions. The non-zero "ground" state of 1 can be explained by considering carefully the structural details of the complex. There are two different superexchange pathways, both provided by the ligand L2-, and thus two different kinds of J values ( a; from now onwards the numbering scheme that will be used is the same with that used in the real structure of 1, see ). The magnetic data, which are indicative of the presence of one unpaired electron for each CuII triad, suggest that one of the pathways is not magnetically operative. Taking into account that (i) J 2 propagates the antiferromagnetic interaction in the three dimensions, and (ii) the quinoxaline bridge is a weak to moderate, but effective mediator of magnetic exchange interactions , we decided to fit the data assuming a negligible value of J 2. Since the J 1 interaction creates pseudo isolated Cu(2)⋯Cu(1)⋯Cu(2) subunits of the type shown in b (see also ), we used the Hamiltonian of Eq. , including a Θ term in an attempt to adjust the low temperature data. Best-fit parameters are J 1 =-10.4(3)cm-1, g =2.057(6) and Θ =+1.1(1)K.  (1)  H = -   J   1   (   S   2   ⋅   S   1   +   S   1   ⋅   S     2   "     )   The obtained J value is in good agreement with reported values involving the exchange interaction between CuII ions through the quinoxaline bridging ligand, which is always weakly to moderately antiferromagnetic . The minimum in the χ M T vs. T plot at 6K () indicates that J 2 (see a) is not strictly zero. It is not possible to calculate accurately the value of this coupling constant for a 3D system with the observed topology, but the positive sign and low value of the Θ term clearly indicate that a very weak ferromagnetic interaction is mediated by the NCO-/NCCO- moieties of L2-.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In summary, the use of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L′ in a reaction with a Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> source has led to the first coordination polymer containing this ligand system, showing that its dianionic tetrandentate form can indeed support metal polymer chemistry when coupled with appropriate ancillary groups. The obtained product is novel in multiple ways, as described, but it also provides a rare example of a rather complicated structural type where the main magnetic exchange interaction is transmitted through only one pathway. Attempts to prepare coordination polymers of other transition metal ions with H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L′ or L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> are in progress.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, the use of H2L' in a reaction with a CuII source has led to the first coordination polymer containing this ligand system, showing that its dianionic tetrandentate form can indeed support metal polymer chemistry when coupled with appropriate ancillary groups. The obtained product is novel in multiple ways, as described, but it also provides a rare example of a rather complicated structural type where the main magnetic exchange interaction is transmitted through only one pathway. Attempts to prepare coordination polymers of other transition metal ions with H2L' or L2- are in progress.

<ce:para view="all">Heating a solution of [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CMe)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>], CuCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L′ (3:1:3) in DMF at 130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in a sealed tube for 6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, followed by slow cooling down to ambient temperature, gave dark green crystals of [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (DMF)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">

With the identity of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> established by crystallography , a convenient synthesis of the pure material was sought under alternative reaction conditions. Thus, the reaction of three equivalents of CuCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> with two equivalents of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L′, in the presence of four equivalents of LiOH<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, in DMF and layering of Et<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (1:1 v/v) onto the resulting olive green solution gave dark green crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; the yield is ∼70%.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text: Heating a solution of [Cu2(O2CMe)4 (H2O)2], CuCl2 and H2L' (3:1:3) in DMF at 130°C in a sealed tube for 6h, followed by slow cooling down to ambient temperature, gave dark green crystals of [Cu3L2Cl2 (DMF)4] n  (1) directly from the reaction solution; the yield was ca. 50% . With the identity of 1 established by crystallography , a convenient synthesis of the pure material was sought under alternative reaction conditions. Thus, the reaction of three equivalents of CuCl2 with two equivalents of H2L', in the presence of four equivalents of LiOH⋅H2O, in DMF and layering of Et2O (1:1 v/v) onto the resulting olive green solution gave dark green crystals of 1; the yield is ~70%.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Solid-state dc magnetic susceptibility data ( ) were collected on dried 1 under a constant field of 0.1T in the temperature range 2.0-300K. The product χ M T at room temperature is 1.17cm3 mol-1 K per trinuclear unit, close to the value of 1.24cm3 mol-1 K expected for three interacting CuII ions with a g value of 2.1. The value of the χ M T product decreases gradually upon cooling until ca. 60K, and below this temperature, it decreases quickly down to a value of 0.62cm3 Kmol-1 at 6K, before increasing sharply at lower temperatures; the χ M T value is 0.81cm3 Kmol-1 at 2.0K. Magnetization experiments performed at 2.0K in the field range 0-5T indicate a saturation value close to one electron per     Cu   3   II     unit exhibiting a Brillouin shape for S =1/2 and g =2.06(4).

For a 3D compound in which all the superexchange pathways were operative and antiferromagnetic in nature, an S =0 "ground state" would be expected in the absence of competitive interactions. The non-zero "ground" state of 1 can be explained by considering carefully the structural details of the complex. There are two different superexchange pathways, both provided by the ligand L2-, and thus two different kinds of J values ( a; from now onwards the numbering scheme that will be used is the same with that used in the real structure of 1, see ). The magnetic data, which are indicative of the presence of one unpaired electron for each CuII triad, suggest that one of the pathways is not magnetically operative. Taking into account that (i) J 2 propagates the antiferromagnetic interaction in the three dimensions, and (ii) the quinoxaline bridge is a weak to moderate, but effective mediator of magnetic exchange interactions , we decided to fit the data assuming a negligible value of J 2. Since the J 1 interaction creates pseudo isolated Cu(2)⋯Cu(1)⋯Cu(2) subunits of the type shown in b (see also ), we used the Hamiltonian of Eq. , including a Θ term in an attempt to adjust the low temperature data. Best-fit parameters are J 1 =-10.4(3)cm-1, g =2.057(6) and Θ =+1.1(1)K.  (1)  H = -   J   1   (   S   2   ⋅   S   1   +   S   1   ⋅   S     2   "     )   The obtained J value is in good agreement with reported values involving the exchange interaction between CuII ions through the quinoxaline bridging ligand, which is always weakly to moderately antiferromagnetic . The minimum in the χ M T vs. T plot at 6K () indicates that J 2 (see a) is not strictly zero. It is not possible to calculate accurately the value of this coupling constant for a 3D system with the observed topology, but the positive sign and low value of the Θ term clearly indicate that a very weak ferromagnetic interaction is mediated by the NCO-/NCCO- moieties of L2-.

Supplementary material

CCDC 663054 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for 1. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

Satisfactory C, H and N analyses were obtained (the product was washed with Et2O and dried in vacuo).

 Crystallographic data. 1: C28H36N8Cu3O8Cl2, M =874.17, tetragonal, I41/a, a = b =24.616(2)Å, c =11.6525(10)Å, V =7060.8(10)cm3, Z =8, D c =1.645gcm-3, μ (synchrotron)=2.619mm-1, T =150(2)K, 19197 reflections collected, 4754 unique (R int =0.0692), R 1 on F(wR 2 on F 2)=0.0453 (0.1255) for 4234 observed (I >2σ(I)) reflections.

cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 8  (a) The 2-J magnetic model initially considered for complex 1. The squared CuII ion belongs to a neighbouring trinuclear unit. (b) The psedoisolated Cu(2)⋯Cu(1)⋯Cu(2") subunits of 1 created through bridging of the "quinoxaline" portion of the ligand L2-. The squared Cu(2) and Cu(2") ions belong to two different repeat trinuclear units in relation to Cu(1). The singly primed and unprimed atoms are related by the crystallographic inversion centre within the repeat trinuclear unit. The numbering scheme used for both a and b is the same with that used in the solution of the structure of 1 (see Fig. 2).

metadata.title: First use of 1,4-dihydro-2,3-quinoxalinedione in the chemistry of coordination polymers: A 3D copper(II) complex containing the 2,3-dioxyquinoxalinate(−2) ligand in a novel coordination mode
